leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 79 COURT OF DISPUTED RETURNS [rr 1–31]
DIVISION 2 DISPUTED ELECTIONS AND RETURNS [rr 6–23]
[SCR Pt 79 r 6] r 6 Application of Division

p.text: This Division applies to proceedings under Division 1 of Part 6 of the subject Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 7] r 7 Interpretation

p.text: For the purposes of rule 4 , unless the context or subject matter otherwise indicates or requires:
means petitioner, and
means respondent.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 8] r 8 Commencement of proceedings

p.text: Proceedings in the Court shall be commenced by petition in the prescribed form, joining as respondent every person the validity of whose election or return is disputed.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 79.8.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Parliamentary Electorates And Elections Act 1912 ss 157–159.
See Form 122 at [454,585] for the prescribed form of, and ss 157–159 of the Parliamentary Electorates and Elections Act 1912 for matters to be included in, a petition.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 79.8.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Parliamentary Electorates And Elections Act 1912 ss 157–159.
Strict compliance with ss 157–159 appears to be necessary: see Re Porter's Election Petition (1923) 31 CLR 600 where a petition by way of telegram was held ineffective.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 79.8.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 17.

A petitioner will be kept strictly to the case made by the petition. Powers of amendment (see SCR Pt 79 r 4 cf SCR Pt 79 r 13) are exercised cautiously: Cameron v Fysh (1904) 1 CLR 314 at 321 ; Crafter v Webster (1980) 23 SASR 61. On the degree of particularity required in a petition see SCR Pt 79 r 17 and Cole v Lacey (1965) 112 CLR 45; 38 ALJR 434 ; Re Surfers Paradise Election Petition; Soegemeier v Small [1975] Qd R 114 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 9] r 9 Publication

p.text: The petitioner shall, forthwith after filing the petition:
publish it in the Gazette, and
publish a notice in the prescribed form in a newspaper circulating in the Electoral District.
See Form 123 at [454,587] for the form of the prescribed notice.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 10] r 10 Service of petition

p.text: The petitioner shall:
at the request of the Electoral Commissioner, serve the petition on the Electoral Commissioner personally,
within seven days after filing the petition, serve the petition on each respondent, other than the Electoral Commissioner, personally.
The request of the Electoral Commissioner under subrule (1) may be added to his notice of appearance.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 11] r 11 Death of party

p.text: Where a sole petitioner dies before the trial, his solicitor or, if he had no solicitor, the respondent on learning of his death, shall file notice of the death.
Where a respondent (other than the Electoral Commissioner) dies before the trial, his solicitor or, if he had no solicitor, the petitioner on learning of his death, shall file notice of the death.

ci:cite.ci:content: cf Representation of the People Act 1949 (Eng) s 134(1) and Election Petition Rules 1960 (Eng) r 16

p.text: The Prothonotary shall publish notice of the death in a newspaper circulating in the Electoral District.

The notice shall add a statement to the effect that any person who might have been a petitioner may, not later than 28 days after the publication of the notice, apply by motion to the Court at such time and place as the Court may appoint, to be substituted as a petitioner or as a respondent as the case may require.
There is no prescribed form of notice under this rule.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 12] r 12 Respondent not opposing petition

p.text: Where, before the trial of a petition, a respondent (other than the Electoral Commissioner) files a notice that he does not intend to oppose a petition, he shall serve the notice on the petitioner and publish the notice in a newspaper circulating in the Electoral District.

ci:cite.ci:content: cf Representation of the People Act 1949 (Eng) s 134(1) and Election Petition Rules 1960 (Eng) rr 15,16

p.text: A notice under subrule (1) shall add a statement to the effect that any person who might have been a petitioner may, not later than 28 days after the publication of the notice, apply by motion to the Court at such time and place as the Court may appoint to be substituted as a respondent.
A respondent who has filed a notice under subrule (1) shall not be allowed to appear or act as a party against the petition.
Where a respondent files a notice under subrule (1) , the Prothonotary shall report that fact to the Clerk of the Legislative Assembly.
There is no prescribed form of notice under this rule.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 13] r 13 Substitution of petitioner or respondent

p.text: The Court may, on application by a person who might have been a petitioner, order that that person be substituted as a petitioner or as a respondent, as the case may require, and may make further orders for the conduct of the proceedings which may include orders relating to:
service of the order and other documents in the proceedings,
amendment, and
the sum required under section 158 of the subject Act as security for costs.

ci:cite.ci:content: cf HCR O 68, r 11 and Representation of the People Act 1949 (Eng) ss 127(1), 134(1)

p.text: Where the Court orders that a party be substituted for another party or a former party, all things done in the proceedings before the making of the order shall, unless the Court otherwise orders, have effect in relation to the new party as those things had effect in relation to the old, but entry of appearance by the old party shall not dispense with entry of appearance by the new.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 14] r 14 Electoral Commissioner

p.text: The Electoral Commissioner may apply to the Court under section 160 of the subject Act (which section relates to leave to enter an appearance) by motion in the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 15] r 15 Time limited for entry of appearance

leg:heading.title: Time limited for entry of appearance

p.text: The time limited for entry of an appearance is:
in the case of the Electoral Commissioner, subject to any order of the Court — 14 days after leave is granted to him to enter an appearance,
in the case of a respondent (other than the Electoral Commissioner) — 14 days after service of the petition upon him,
in the case of any other person who might have been a petitioner — 14 days after the publication of the petition in the Gazette.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 16] r 16 No step without appearance

p.text: A person, other than a petitioner or the Electoral Commissioner, shall not, except by leave of the Court, take any step in any proceedings unless, before taking the step, he has filed a petition under the subject Act or has entered an appearance in the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 17] r 17 Particulars

p.text: The Court may order any party to file and serve on any other party particulars or further and better particulars of any matter alleged by him.
On the degree of particularity required in a petition see Cole v Lacey (1965) 112 CLR 45; 38 ALJR 434 and Re Surfers Paradise Election Petition; Soegemeier v Small [1975] Qd R 114 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 18] r 18 Motions

p.text: An interlocutory or other application, in or for the purposes of or in relation to the proceedings, shall be made by motion under the rules.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 19] r 19 Discontinuance

p.text: Proceedings may not be discontinued without the leave of the Court.
Where there are two or more petitioners, an application for leave under subrule (1) may not be made, except with the consent of all the petitioners.
The Court may give leave under subrule (1) on terms.
An application under subrule (1) should be made by motion at such time and place as the Court appoints.

The notice of motion for leave under subrule (1) shall state the grounds on which the application is made and add a statement to the effect that, on the hearing of the motion, any person who might have been a petitioner in respect of the election may apply to the Court to be substituted as a petitioner.
Not less than 14 days before the day appointed under subrule (4) , the petitioner shall publish the notice of motion in a newspaper circulating in the Electoral District.
Evidence on an application for leave under subrule (1) shall include evidence denying, subject to any specified exceptions:
that any agreement or terms of any kind whatsoever has or have been made, and
that any undertaking has been entered into,
in relation to the discontinuance in respect of which leave is sought.

ci:cite.ci:content: cf Representation of the People Act 1949 (Eng) s 128

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 20] r 20 Lists of objections to votes

p.text: This rule applies where the petition (not being a petition merely claiming a fresh count of the votes counted at the election) claims the seat for a person not returned, alleging that that person had a majority of valid votes.

Each party shall, not later than 14 days before the day appointed for the trial, serve on the opposite party a list of the votes or class of votes which he contends were improperly admitted or improperly rejected, stating, in respect of each, the grounds of the contention.
[subr (2) am Amendment 188: Gaz 151 of 26 September 1986 p 4709 ]
A contention under subrule (2) by a party shall not be entertained upon a ground not specified in his list, except with the leave of the Court.
The Court may give leave under subrule (3) on terms.
There is no prescribed form of list.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 21] r 21 Respondent's contention of undue election

p.text: Where a petition claims a seat for a person not returned and a respondent wishes to contend, upon a ground not mentioned in rule 20(2) , that that person was not duly elected, he shall, not later than 14 days before the day appointed for the trial, serve on the petitioner a statement of the facts upon which he intends to rely and the grounds of the contention.
[r 21 am Amendment 188: Gaz 151 of 26 September 1986 p 4709]
There is no prescribed form of statement of facts and contentions.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 22] r 22 Trial

p.text: The trial shall be held at a time and place to be appointed by the Court at the request of a party.
Not less than 14 days' notice of the time and place appointed shall:
be given by the party obtaining the order to the other parties, and
be published by the party obtaining the order in a newspaper circulating in the Electoral District.
The time and place of trial may be varied from time to time by the Court.
This rule does not affect the powers of the Court as to adjournment.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 79 r 23] r 23 Evidence generally

p.text: Division 1 of Part 31 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (which relates to evidence generally) applies on the trial of a petition as it applies on a trial in proceedings commenced by statement of claim.
[r 23 am Gaz 99 of 5 August 2005 r 3 and Sch 1 item [123], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 79.23.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Parliamentary Electorates And Elections Act 1912 s 166.

Reference should also be made to the subject Act: see [79.0.0] . Section 166 , to the extent that it relaxes laws of evidence, would prevail over these rules; but it remains a procedural section only: Crafter v Webster (No 2) (1980) 23 SASR 321 .
